text: [Music]
hi
i'm eric brewer and i'm happy to speak
to you virtually today
about the lessons from kubernetes which
are lessons i hope will be useful to the
ray community
so my bigger goal in general is to make
it possible to build cloud native
applications
and we're in the middle of this
transition it's about five years in
i would say it starts with things like
the view that there's infinite resources
in the cloud and you can get them
quickly and as many as you like
we tend to think about services and not
machines
we tend to think about apis and
co-design
and how we want our services to work
together and finally we expect that
we'll have high availability
for everything we depend on and
everything we offer
so that's our goal how do we build those
kinds of applications
and the good news is google's been doing
this in a while for at least 15 years
at least the use of containers and
coming up
with docker and its revolution we kind
of saw an opportunity to say ah
docker is kind of like what we do we
were using containers internally mostly
to simplify application management but
also for performance isolation so we can
run many
applications on the same machine docker
has a packaging format that makes that
easier so
our use of linux containers their use of
packaging worked well together and that
really led to kubernetes
and what i want out of kubernetes is
this higher level of abstraction so
in kubernetes you should be thinking
about things like how do my services fit
together
things like load balancing should be
kind of built in right every
service has load balancing needs the
names of services should be something
that are a first class thing
compared to say ip addresses or dns
addresses
we should be able to help estate
management and with monitoring and
logging
and most of all we should be able to
help with upgrading because the goal
here again is high availability
how do we get our services to be both
high velocity meaning lots of feature
changes but also highly available even
while they're being upgraded
conversely if we do this right things
you don't have to think about are the
details of the operating system
don't have to worry about packages or
dll conflicts
right those cause much problems when
you're trying to run multiple
applications on the same machine
in fact the machine itself you shouldn't
have to carry too much about we really
would like to have an
abstract machine with you know whatever
number of cpus you happen to need in
fact if you look at modern gke
as a whole way to automatically
provision nodes on your behalf
another big one is different languages
right everyone has their favorite
language and they have different
favorite languages for
different aspects so ideally every team
should be able to use whatever languages
they want and have it all work together
in the service infrastructure
and even little things that caused us
lots of trouble internally were fixed in
kubernetes
my favorite is port conflicts when your
multiple applications on the same
machine
which one gets port 80 for example and
the answer in kubernetes is
every pod has its own set of ip
addresses
and ports and therefore the problem goes
away
that's the high level abstraction we
should be after
but what we're really after is one more
step which is velocity
how i think about that is it's it's
evolution
and we do this because we have abstract
services so ideally
the service is itself actually just a
name right for an api
and the implementation of that api
varies over time those are the versions
and kubernetes is version aware and
service aware so it can route to the
right
versions it can actually help with other
kinds of things like canary testing
or blue gold deployments things where
you do special rollouts
that's really an important part of the
infrastructure
the other way to think about this is the
kind of the team view
that when you're using many services as
the structure for your application
it means that you can mix the languages
but you also mix the teams
so when i look at you know what kinds of
projects are high velocity
it's really when different teams can
deploy independently
right independent upgrade and mixture of
teams mixture of language that's what
gives you both high availability and
high velocity
so an important lesson really the first
and obvious lesson
most obvious lesson for kubernetes is
the value of open source
and it's worth pointing out that
kubernetes didn't have to be open source
that was actually a somewhat difficult
decision for google to make
and in the end we made it for a few
different reasons that are worth
covering
first kubernetes is too big a change
right
we would like to make a you know massive
change in how applications are built
even google despite its size is not big
enough to make that change on its own
right a lot of buy-in not only from all
the cloud players but really from all
the enterprises and from all
the infrastructure that supports these
systems
that was a first big reason that led us
to create the cncf
cloud native computing foundation uh
which is actually
now more than five years old in fact i
gave the original kubernetes talk in
at dockercon and so it was within that
first year we actually created this
foundation
and that really is the place to house
not only kubernetes
but all of the ecosystem which i'll get
to in a minute
[Music]
a second reason for open source is a
little more subtle but i think
actually the main compelling one to me
which is that
traditionally the way you would
standardize something is you'd write a
specification down
and that works well for things like
airplanes
or parts that don't change much
so if you look at the traditional iso
standard for example it's a written down
thing that you all agree on
but that process takes years conversely
kubernetes changes every quarter in a
material way
and a normal specification based process
wouldn't work for that
so really the goal here is that the code
is in fact the de facto standard
and we need to make that work and that
use of the code is the standard means we
get high velocity as well
the third big value of open source which
i think is a classic one is kind of the
broad customized use
right google's not going to build
kubernetes by itself the way that
everyone wants to consume it and you
know you saw this originally on
extensive use of kubernetes on-prem
right not even in the cloud
and then that in turn enabled hybrid and
multi-cloud versions and that's the
giant industry now
but also much smaller versions like
telco edges and even raspberry pi's so
this
broad use where it's customized for the
environment that's also part of open
source has made the reach of kubernetes
much larger than it would have been
otherwise
second lesson from kubernetes that i
think is a
a pretty fundamental one to think about
how to copy
is what i call the innovation tree and
you can think of the tree as starting
as a sapling with a trunk and in the
early days of kubernetes this would be
2014 or even the work before it was
public in 2013
this is all about the trunk right it's
what are the core things like the api

all that stuff was kind of in the core

but that soon led to other efforts like

that you can think of as the major

tree the major branches sorry and so
this led to a sig structure special

you know more than 10 special interest
groups that actually
specialize in different parts of
kubernetes or really different parts of
cloud native and this allows those
groups to work in parallel
and i think that's really the the big
point here is that
this structure has given us parallel
innovation
all the innovation is actually the
leaves and in fact the core is actually

and in part uh kubernetes made another

a bit better than it might have been

particularly the custom resource

those allow extensions in a way that are

enabling
specialization and lots of leaves and

that's led to a tremendous amount of

thousands of people
if you take that one step further you

the success is actually not just the

this stuff has to work and it has to be

and yet it also is undergoing a high

is lots and lots of mundane work
one of my favorite kinds of mundane work
is enabling testing
and people have always said oh you need

but i think it's an extra level of
importance now
that is worth repeating and the reason
for this is
you can't really have high velocity if
you don't have test cases
because you want other people to make
good changes to your system
and when they do they need to know if
their changes will break stuff
and the only way they can know that is
if you have test cases
and so an important kind of mundane work
is test cases that are good enough
to detect breaking changes this also by
the way is how we do the de facto
standardization through conformance
testing
conformance tests are essentially here's
what we think the standard is and here's
how to tell if you're meeting it
if you make a change that breaks the
conformance test you're not conforming
that is an important part of this kind
of standardization
the kind based on code that i think is
critical for both open source and for
high velocity
so to wrap up kubernetes has been a
tremendous journey for me personally and
for google
the vision is pretty simple we're
building a new kind of cloud
that runs at a higher level of
extraction not machines and disks but
actually services and apis
and yet we want it to run all the things
so kubernetes in particular
is a platform for all the platforms
it's also pointing out at this point
that kubernetes won
i think there's no debate that it is the

and that's why i hope ray will be viewed

as the default way to build and use it

the lessons open source is the key part
